title: Can you legally name a person all lowercase letters and make it incorrect to write their name with an uppercase starting letter? - Quora

response.answer_text: Interesting question. President Truman’s middle “name” was just S … no period after it and the S didn’t stand for anything. Still, most put the period there despite many (in his time) being told not to by the man himself. My first name has only on “L” but half or more of the people who know me spell it incorrectly despite the fact that they know better. I once was in a war of sorts with an HR clerk who kept fixing my name after I’d go into the system and correct the spelling. I have no doubt you could spell the name in all lowercase on the birth certificate. I’ve seen some debate about whether or not whoever is writing it down can refuse to accept anything other than what they believe to be a proper name. A nurse refused to write down Dweezil for the Zappa’ son, so they had to change it (to Richard, I think … short for … well …). Legal, who knows but you’re probably not thinking “let’s get the lawyer while our kid goes as no name.” (Dweezil changed his first name to that as an adult, so that’s long been his legal name.) But lots of luck “making it incorrect” for anyone to spell it otherwise. It’s incorrect to spell my name with two ells, but how exactly would I stop anyone from doing it? Sue hundreds of people constantly? And how does that stop the next person? You’d have a fight with schools, doctors and who knows who else. But who I’d really sympathize with is the kid because that’s who’s going to take more s**t than you could ever imagine over this.

I always knew my last name as “van Ammers” with a lower case ‘v’, with a space, and with an uppercase ‘A’. That’s how it was in the country of my birth (the Netherlands). Here in the U.S.A., clerks and/or computers will usually change the lowercase ‘v’ to an uppercase ‘V’ and often times they will remove the space. I correct it when I can. My naturalization certificate, which is my U.S.A. official identification document shows my name as “MARNIX ALEXANDER van AMMERS”. I don’t know how or why it went like that. Why not all upper case? Why not mixed case? On any form I always write my complete name as “Marnix Alexander van Ammers”. I deliberately use two spaces between my middle name and my last name in the hope that intelligent computers might grok that the two spaces separate the last name from the rest. I would say that it’s “incorrect” for my name to be written anywhere other than the way I write it, but to a clerk somewhere it might be an unbreakable rule that a name has to be written with the first (or all) letter(s) being upper case. I don’t know that there is any law governing this.

There’s a web page that I strongly encourage everyone to read called the Idiot Legal Arguments page. It was created by a lawyer named Bernard J. Sussman and it’s a compendium of all the ridiculous things people have tried to avoid paying their taxes. He has a whole section on cases where the defendant claimed that the court papers were invalid because they didn’t use the defendant’s preferred typography, such as all caps, wacky pronunciation like an asterisk between each pair of letters. You name it. Those arguments never work. If you want the chance to be the first one to win a case with this argument, feel free to go to court and say to the judge, “Your Honor, I don’t know who this John Smith guy is. My name is J*O*H*N S*M*I*T*H.” You’ll be lucky if getting laughed out of court is the worst thing that happens to you. Oh, but do follow the link and read some of the Idiot Legal Arguments. It is definitely worth it.

I am not a lawyer, but I suspect that in the United States there is no provision for enforcing the use of upper and lower case letters. You can ask that your name be spelled with only lowercase letters and this will generally be followed by the media, publishing houses, etc. The poet e. e. cummings is an example that readily comes to mind. He liked his name to be spelled in only one case: all upper case or all lower case. In spite of this, note that both the Poetry Foundation and Wikipedia spell his name with the conventional upper case/lower case combination.

if you can ‘legally’ name a person all lower case you can try to stop people/the administration spelling your name in upper case or lower case, but have fun trying to. You will probably spend more time trying and waste everybody else’s time. You will probably end up trying everyone’s patience to the point that they won’t want to deal with you anymore, thereby nullifying any good feelings. I strongly suspect there are concise rules in naming laws, not only in the UK, that determine how you start names. When it comes to it, it is the spelling that counts, not whether it is upper or lower case.

From what I have seen, many government databases store all names in one case (say, upper case). So if the record system in the state or county where a birth is registered is like this, it will make no difference whether somebody writes his surname McDonald or Mcdonald, or whether someone is d’Artgagnan, D’Artagnan, or D’artagnan — internally, it will be recorded the same (in all caps… and some systems may even replace O with 0). In other words, the government does not concern itself with capitalization. I am sure some jurisdictions may be more advanced… but don’t count on this.

Well, as I once knew a chap who changed his name - all of it - by Deed Poll, to Gnome, and someone else reportedly christened their baby ‘Uranus’, (Mum shares the VERY unique spelling of her daughter's name - but what do you think?) lower case insistence sounds relatively benign… Good luck to whomever, with enforcing it, though! And everyone will, perpetually, just think s/he can’t even punctuate her/his own name.

Only if you’re e.e. cummings. Serious answer: No. As far as the law is concerned, there’s no difference between “A” and “a”, between “B” and “b”, between “C” and “c”, or any other uppercase/lowercase letter pair. (Many writing systems don’t even distinguish between uppercase and lowercase letters. Examples include Arabic, Bengali, Chinese, Devanagari, and Kana. These five writing systems, collectively, have about 2.2 billion users and they’re not the only ones.)

If you, personally, are applying for a name change, I suggest you check with your local government for a ruling on this issue. If you are naming a newborn, the same. My daugher wanted to name her newborn son Andre, with an accent over the e but learned California does not permit accented letters.
There are a few English surnames that should not have initial uppercase. ffrench is one example.
